Yes I admit I said very terrible things but I seriously think that I shouldn't be permanently banned. Please help people.

replies.body: I was just really salty and tilted because people in my ranked games were trying to purposely lose and I'm not sure if anyone would understand their purpose of playing the game. I am truly sorry for my actions though and I think that I can do much better if you just won't ban me. This account had lots of RP spent on it too.

> I am truly sorry for my actions though and I think that I can do much better if you just won't ban me.

You were given numerous chances to reform.

2x 10-game chat restriction
25-game chat restriction
14-day ban

Each of those punishments was us telling you that your behavior was unacceptable and a chance to reform. You were even told in your 14-day ban that the next would result in a perma-ban.

> [{quoted}](name=Riot Tantram,realm=NA,application-id=ZGEFLEUQ,discussion-id=m8fBAsU9,comment-id=00060002,timestamp=2016-03-21T21:00:07.116+0000)

> You were given numerous chances to reform.
> 
> 2x 10-game chat restriction
> 25-game chat restriction
> 14-day ban
> 
> Each of those punishments was us telling you that your behavior was unacceptable and a chance to reform. You were even told in your 14-day ban that the next would result in a perma-ban.

Instead of that why don't riot introduce a system that gives you your behavior status report every week so people might actually reform because they can constantly overview their state(because people dont check emails often) and not get perma banned only to go make another account making low elo and beginner level player's lives a living hell and spreading more toxicity(feeding and etc).This gives them a bad experience and they might even stop playing because of such issues.
I honestly think this is better.

I understand what you're saying, and there are some merits. However we want people to always exhibit good sportsmanship, not just when they think they are at risk of punishment.

Our systems take into account that everyone has a bad day from time to time. We generally don't penalize a player for a single offense but instead penalize players who exhibit a history of poor sportsmanship or something extreme that we must act on (ie hate speech).

We understand people can have a bad day. We think a 10-game chat restriction is a great way of telling players that their fellow summoners think their behavior is unacceptable, and the huge majority of players we give them to never see another punishment. When a player escalates through the entire schedule we need to ask whether that player will ever turn their behavior around or whether they are more apt to ruin games for others who are just looking to have fun.

We are always looking for a better player experience so I am certainly always open to hearing ideas that players have. Providing reform cards was on of those points of feedback that we recently implemented.

I don't imagine that leveling a new account's particularly difficult for an LCS-caliber player. Honestly, it's probably only a mild inconvenience at best. He knows what to do, he can basically beat everybody pre-30 and get back to where he should be very quickly.  He knows exactly what he's good at, what champs/runes he needs, and can get them easily. Then they can get tournament money again and unlocking anything becomes a non-issue.

The better you are at the game, the easier it is to get your footing back on a new account. Players who aren't that good are basically back to working with scraps on the long grind back to where they can actually experiment and find what works for them.

It is their fault, though, and I can concede to that. It's just that, even if a lesser-skilled player WANTS to reform and level a new account, and continue supporting Riot and your game, the mere idea of having to endure this entire grind a second time makes it not even feel worth it. 

It's even worse when you can't queue with your friends due to you basically being a handicap to them on your new account. In my case, I've been putting myself under a considerable amount of stress trying to level by myself, after I'd already figured out that trying to play by myself is exactly WHY I got stressed to the point where I went off and got banned.

Sorry if that went off on a bit of a tangent. I guess I'm just wondering what sort of advice a Rioter would offer in this type of situation. The Rioter I talked with on one of my support tickets basically told me to "play with friends and earn hextech rewards". Except, like I said, my friends are level 30s and that just screws up the matchmaking something fierce, especially when pre-30 matchmaking is already somewhat imbalanced by the presence of smurfs.

I actually tried to. My 'toxicity' was being caused by my own lack of confidence rather than any actual contempt for other players, though, so solving my problem wasn't as simple as "mute and report".

My 14-day and permanent bans were nearly 3 months apart. The problem there became that not only did I have to solve all my problems, I had to do so perfectly due to being on thin ice, and having no way of knowing how 'close' I was to either reform OR a ban. I actually didn't play too much in that time _(relatively speaking)_ out of fear that I'd lose my account.

I'll leave it at that, though. This isn't my thread.

I think it should be difficult to make a new account once you've been permabanned. A person has to be absurdly oblivious and self-centered to get to that point, and they're probably not going to change. I sure as hell don't want to play with anyone who's been permabanned.

its not just for 3 games. They can only send 3 games to you as example. 

if you didn't know, there are 4 tiers of punishment;

1. 10 Game chat restriction
2. 25 Game chat restriction
3. 14 day ban
4. Permaban

An accumulation of offenses will get you punished. Everytime you get punished, you move up the tiers (extreme cases can skip tiers). 

So with this new system, its lesser about "MY CHAT WAS SUPER OFFENSIVE!!!!", but more about "how often were you offensive". You've accumulated offenses (and were reported) enough times to work through the punishment tiers, and now the final punishment has arrived. 

We don't want your current behavior in the community. If you wish, you can start a new account and be nice. Keep in mind that its easier to get banned again with bad behavior has Riot already has their eyes on you when you start a new account.

Account sharing is technically a bannable offense in itself, even though it's rarely enforced...
But what logically follows, and what Riot has always been clear and strict about, is that unless you get hacked, you will be taken responsible for every action that happens on your account.
If you gave your brother access to your account, you are responsible for the things he does and says.
No like he played league first and I just got the account after him cos he said he was going to stop playing.

Let's ignore for a second that account "trading" is just as much breaking the rules as sharing it...
If you are the owner of the account, you are responsible for your brothers' actions while he was playing on your account.
If he is the owner of the account, he is responsible for his actions while he was playing on his account.
If you shared equally, the both of you are responsible for each others' actions while playing on your account.

The exact circumstances don't really matter. It was not unauthorized access, and whoever played on it, misbehaved to the extent where the **account** (not the player) was permanently banned. Whoever was "in charge" of the account should have taken better care of how the players that have access behave while using it.
